column13: Mirvac has one of AustraliaÃ¢ÂÂs greenest office portfolios, with 17 office assets rated 5 Star NABERS Energy or higher. Mirvac's operating assets are supplied with 100 per cent renewable electricity, progressively electrifying its assets. Mirvac also has high waste diversion rates across construction and operations.

column6: Reduction of GHG emissions
column13: In FY23, Mirvac constructed its first Green Star Home at Waverley Park in Victoria. The home raises the bar for environmental and social sustainability as part of MirvacÃ¢ÂÂs commitment to creating outstanding living environments that leave a positive legacy. The house is a fully electric home and the most substantial GBCA-certified Green Star Home built to date. The home achieved a 7.8 Star NatHERS rating and has a 10kW solar panel system, making it one of Mirvac's highest-performing homes in terms of energy bills and renewable energy consumption.
column20: Green Star Home, Waverley Park, fully-electric home

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: A standout circularity project in the financial year was at Harbourside Shopping Centre in Sydney as Mirvac undertook vacant possession. Together with Mates on The Move, a work program run by Prisoners Aid NSW, Mirvac removed over 4,000 unwanted items weighing 22 tonnes, such as furniture and kitchen equipment valued at more than $320,000, delivered to local charities and businesses.
column20: Mates on The Move, circularity project, Harbourside Shopping Centre

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: Mirvac's in-house team conducted waste audits with social enterprise partners at several retail centres and office assets to understand landfill waste composition and feedback recycling opportunities for customers.
column20: Waste audit, social enterprise, waste composition

column6: Management of significant waste-related impacts
column13: This year, Mirvac worked with Boral on a trial to change the procurement and management of concrete at its Green Square project in Sydney. By connecting the supply and take-back of materials, waste concrete is reduced by 50 per cent, with 99.6 per cent of concrete waste recycled back into construction materials.

New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Mirvac makes significant inroads in its Women in Construction program. Through targeted efforts, women made up 32 per cent of new hires in construction in the past year, increasing their representation in this part of the business to 18 per cent, up from 15 per cent in FY22. The program also continues Mirvac's focus on developing female leaders at Mirvac, with initiatives to help them acquire new skills, network with other senior leaders, and gain experience to advance their careers.
column20: Women in Construction, new hire, female leader

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column7: By building a diverse, inclusive, performance-oriented, and collaborative culture, Mirvac can continue to give itself a competitive advantage and inspire its people to deliver on its goals and urban strategy.

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column13: Supporting the mental health and wellbeing of its people is an important focus for Mirvac, and through FY23, Mirvac further embedded its wellbeing strategy by expanding its offering. Mirvac continued the partnership with Sonder, which provides employees and their families access to support from a network of trained safety, health, and wellbeing specialists all year round.

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: In FY23, Mirvac delivered major hazard review sessions across the Commercial and mixed-use projects, emphasising identifying hazards with the highest consequences for Mirvac and then workshopping appropriate solutions to prevent such events.

column6: Occupational health services
column13: Through premium mental health and wellbeing provider Mindstar, Mirvac offered personalised support for employees struggling with mental health.

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: Mirvac acknowledges there is a growing need to provide its people leaders with the necessary skills to care for themselves and others in the context of mental health and wellbeing. People leaders are usually the first port of call for employees who may be affected by mental health issues and are the first line of defence in managing psychological hazards. Mirvac developed a pilot program to upskill leaders. It was delivered in FY23, and people leaders across the business will receive this training in FY24.
column20: People leader, mental health, psychological hazard

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: Mirvac has an active network of over 60 mental health first aiders. Throughout FY23, their approach has evolved to prioritise active listening and initial triaging before guiding people to either Sonder or Mindstar.
column20: Mental Health First Aiders, Sonder, Mindstar

column6: Promotion of worker health
column13: Mirvac'sHealth, Safety & Environment Policy sets out the guiding principles and its commitment to protect and improve the health, safety and wellbeing of employees, suppliers and communities and provide healthy, safe and productive places. Mirvac recognises that unsafe workplaces may be linked to an increased likelihood of modern slavery occurring, including in its supply chain.
column20: Health, Safety & Environment Policy, employee, supplier

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column7: During the financial year, Mirvac moved from a traditional physical injury prevention model towards one that prioritises preventing major unwanted events and providing holistic care for its team.

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column7: Mirvac's approach to safety continues to prioritise major hazards, particularly to prevent high-consequence incidents across its portfolio. Key to this is a need for curiosity and for leaders to adopt a 'chronic unease' mindset, encouraging people to seek out any shortcomings in Mirvac's existing approach, even when things are going well.

column7: In 2023, 99.6% of Mirvac employees received training.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Mirvac aims to equip its people with skills and experience across its integrated model to enable them to transition between Mirvac's diverse asset classes. In line with this, Mirvac facilitated its targeted development program, LEED (Leadership, Experience, Exposure, Development), in FY23. The program aims to enhance leadership capability among Mirvac's key talent to enable them to grow as adaptive leaders.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Mirvac's innovation program, Hatch by Mirvac, has helped create a strong innovation culture and capability since its establishment in 2014. It has underpinned Mirvac's value of being curious and bold and contributed to an attractive employment brand for the next generation of employees seeking to work for innovative organisations.
column20: Hatch by Mirvac, innovation program, innovation culture

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: The Hatch by Mirvac team led an innovation project with the largest cohort of interns. Over 35 interns were trained on Mirvac's innovation methodology, and research was conducted to identify applications of Generative AI across the organisation. These insights will form part of a broader work undertaken by Mirvac's Digital team to develop a pipeline of Generative AI applications.
column20: Innovation methodology, innovation project, Generative AI
